basicInfo.description: The japanese camellia is a small tree or shrub with glossy green leaves and showy white, pink or red flowers. Native to Japan, it has since spread around the world and is widely cultivated as an ornamental plant, even becoming the official state flower of the U.S. state of Alabama. In China, it is considered a symbol of good luck and is a staple of many New Year's celebrations.

distribution.distributionSummary: Japanese camellia is native to east Asia. Although not widely distributed in the wild, it has been introduced in other Asian countries. Japanese camellia prefers to grow in hilly woodland areas at sea level near the coast, and is appreciated as an ornamental for gardens with suitable climates around the world.

list.title: Economic Value
list.value: Oils can be extracted; tree trunks are strong and durable; can be used to make furniture; or can be made into charcoal, to make charcoal carvings and other handicrafts.

list.title: Garden Use
list.value: Japanese camellia is an evergreen woody tree or shrub commonly found in gardens. It is prized for its rich foliage and long-lasting glorious blooms. It has dense foliage and is often planted as a shade-providing flowering screen. Japanese camellia is often used in Japanese-style or Pollinator gardens. Plant Crocuses, Japanese Spurge, or Tulips for color contrast.

list.title: Interesting Facts
list.value: The camellia always blossoms quietly in the courtyard while it is still chilly in early spring. Different from other flowers, the camellia flower will not wither in its entirety. Instead, it will wither carefully and slowly one by one until the end of its life. Is it in this same manner that people pursue their ideal companion? ThatÃ¢ÂÂs how the flower symbolizes ideal love.

values: The latin name Camellia is evolved from the name of the Moravian botanist, Joseph Kamel ('Camellus'). This plant is the most common species of Camellia, so it is called the common camellia.

When most of the flowers are still escaping from the cold winter, they have already entered the budding phase. As the flower resembles rose under harsh conditions, it is being known as the rose of winter.

identifyList: Glossy, leathery leaves measuring 2-3 inches (5-7.6 cm) with finely serrated edges.
Prominent, axillary double flowers 3-5 inches (7.6-12.7 cm) in diameter, blooming in late winter to early spring.
Woody capsule fruit around 1 inch (2.54 cm) in length, changing color upon maturity.
Dark brown stem with blackish lenticels, crescent-shaped leaf scars, and coarse texture.
Alternate, simple leaves 2-4 inches (5-10 cm) long, with ovate to elliptic shape and serrated margins.

summarys.title: Water
summarys.value: Originating from Japan's humid forests, japanese camellia thrives in consistent humidity with moderate drought tolerance. Water every 1-2 weeks, keeping soil moist but not waterlogged. Grown as an ornamental outdoor shrub in temperate climates, japanese camellia also adapts well to container living to prevent root rot.

summarys.title: Fertilize
summarys.value: Fertilize japanese camellia with balanced nutrients during spring and mid-summer. Use a diluted solution monthly while actively growing, and stop in fall and winter. Water japanese camellia before applying fertilizers to prevent root burn, as over-fertilizing can harm the plant's health.

summarys.title: Pruning
summarys.value: Japanese camellia features glossy leaves and bright blooms, requiring careful pruning in late spring, post-flowering. Trim dead or weak branches to enhance air circulation and shape, but avoid heavy cuts to reduce stress. Proper timing and gentle techniques lead to healthier growth and improved blooms in future seasons.

summarys.title: Propagation
summarys.value: To propagate japanese camellia successfully, use healthy semi-hardwood cuttings, making clean cuts below leaf nodes. Apply rooting hormone and plant in well-draining soil. Maintain high humidity and indirect light; regular misting enhances conditions for rooting.

summarys.title: Repotting
summarys.value: Repot japanese camellia every 2-3 years in spring, using a larger, well-draining container with acidic soil. After repotting, place japanese camellia in indirect light, keep the soil moist, and refrain from fertilizing for a month to support recovery.
